caption: What does it look like when we truly listen to one another?A View of Things to Come brings together voices not often heard ex-offender artists and seniors in a shared conversation about change, hope, and possibility.Held at The Arts House at The Old Parliament from 9 January 2026 to 31 January 2026, the exhibition features 8 original paintings by artists from community partner CANVAS, displayed alongside poems written by seniors from St Luke's ElderCare. Together, these works imagine a future shaped by empathy, dialogue, and second chances.Formerly trained at the Visual Arts Hub within the Singapore Prison Service, the artists' journeys extend beyond the canvas. Hear from the artists themselves as they share insights into their work and their journey so far!YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Whether it was a mitigation plea or a letter to a loved one, helping his fellow inmates express their thoughts clearly sparked Nabil's interest in pursuing law after his release. Now in his final year of law school at .sg, he looks back at the boy who was expelled and subsequently incarcerated, and hopes to be part of the process of giving second chances. To him, a second chance is society's way of ensuring no one is left behind.YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

Two lives, once defined by addictions and losses, found each other and a reason for them to change. Azlinda and Hairi first met as colleagues, but behind the smiles at work, they were both hiding their own battles with drugs. Years of drug addiction only cost them freedom, family, and broken trust. From heartbreaking losses to moments of hitting rock bottom, they overcame what many thought was impossible.Together, they chose a different path. Through rehabilitation, education, and unwavering support from each other, they rebuilt their lives and founded .sg, a community for those still looking for their own second chance.Their journey tells us that it is never too late to reclaim your life. YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

"A son still sees his father as his hero. A daughter still sees her father as her first love." For Bramsha Osman, the heart of his volunteer journey began long before he stepped forward as a prison volunteer. Raised by grandparents who cared deeply for children in their community, he grew up witnessing the power of love, stability and guidance. That early grounding shaped his belief that every child deserves a father who shows up, both emotionally and spiritually.As he continued volunteering, he saw one heartbreaking pattern emerge repeatedly: fatherlessness. It was this realisation that led him to the Centre for Fathering and eventually to the Singapore Prison Service, where he now supports incarcerated fathers through workshops, open visits and reunification activities. Seeing their fears, hopes and determination to reconnect with their children motivates him to keep showing up week after week.Bramsha's volunteerism allows him to journey alongside fathers from all walks of life, especially those who are currently incarcerated or have been released. He holds the firm belief that when a father chooses to grow, reflect, and reconnect, it changes not just his life but his child's future too, and that is why he serves. YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

On 22 Nov 2025, I partnered with and Industrial and Services Co-operative Society Limited (ISCOS) to deliver my "Shape Your Business" workshop for the entrepreneurial desistors community!For desistor entrepreneurs, being able to fluently share their business propositions and ideas is pivotal in todays world, and learning to tell their business stories with clarity, confidence, and impact is a key step toward taking their ventures to greater heights. This workshop was specially designed to help them better articulate the businesses they are building, showcase their journeys, and connect with wider audiences in a way that truly resonates.workshop training BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonSG

The season of giving is here! Thank you for another wonderful year of supporting our events and activations across Singapore in 2025. We handed out a lot of merchandise to you at these events, but we still have more to give!From now till the 26th of December 2025, stand a chance to win exclusive Yellow Ribbon Merchandise. Heres how:1 Comment with some words of encouragement in support of inmates and ex-offenders2 Follow our page, !3 Tag your family or loved one that youd love to share this merch with2 lucky winners from each of our pages across Facebook, Instagram and TikTok will be the proud owners of our merch. Best of luck!PLEASE NOTE:We have not authorised any individuals or groups to reach out to our followers on our behalf for any purpose, nor do we ask our followers to click on any links. Winners for our giveaways will be notified via DM on our official accounts.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject sggiveaway

Celebrating achievements as we embrace second chances! 23 supervisees have completed a hybrid training pathway that started in Changi Prison Complex and continued at . This pilot SkillsFuture Career Transition Programme (SCTP) in Environmental Services Specialist has allowed supervisees to gain hands-on experience, build confidence in a real-world training environment and accelerate their journey towards meaningful employment.This is complemented by the SIM People Development Fund (SIMPDF), that signed a three-year Memorandum of Understanding with Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), committing up to $150,000 through the SIMPDF Progression Awards to support supervisees on Community-based Programme. This aims to uplift more than 200 supervisees in their reintegration journeys.Graced by Guest-of-Honour, Acting Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs and Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs, , the event included the presentation of the SIMPDF Progression Award to the supervisees. This recognition celebrated their dedication and efforts in paving the way for brighter futures.From 2026, YRSG will expand these training pathways, offering more programmes across a wider range of sectors to help supervisees strengthen their skills and long-term employability. Examples include the retail, food services, beauty and wellness sectors.This is a reminder that with the right support and opportunities, every step forward can open the door to a new beginning. YellowRibbonSingapore YRSG SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

This festive season, we would like to invite you to step aboard our first-ever Roving Art Gallery at , launched yesterday by our Guest-of-Honour, Associate Professor , Acting Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs and Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs, as we shine a light on the gift of second chances, hope and family.Have an up-close look at the inspiring Star Light, Star Bright paintings that were created by incarcerated mothers together with their children, as part of our Star Light, Star Bright initiative, in partnership with and .While you are there, you can pledge your support for the initiative by voting for your favourite paintings, and receive a complimentary set of limited-edition Star Light, Star Bright greeting cards. Whats more, be the first 50 visitors between 6 to 8pm on 6 and 7 December to vote, and receive an exclusive Geneco Green Starter Kit (worth $40), that consists of a foldable umbrella, collapsible lunch box, reusable straw, and tote bag.With your pledges, Geneco will be donating $10,000 to Yellow Ribbon Fund, to support their reintegration efforts for inmates, ex-offenders and their families.If you would like to further support Yellow Ribbons efforts, you can also adopt an artwork at the art gallery. These artworks were crafted by inmate-artists, each reflecting their own passage towards reconciliation with their families. As we celebrate this season of giving, you can also purchase festive cookies from Yellow Ribbon Bakery as festive gifts onsite. These exclusive cookie bundles come in limited-edition packaging featuring the Star Light, Star Bright paintings. A portion of every purchase supports community programmes for ex-offenders and their families.The roving art gallery will travel to Plaza next, from 8 to 14 December, and 270 Orchard Road (outside Adidas), from 15 to 21 December.Let's PowerTheChange and create a brighter world for good, but, most of all, a better home for all.Geneco GenecoSG StarLightStarBrightSG NewBeginningsAhead SharingHope BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Whats more, be the first 50 visitors between 6 to 8pm on 6 and 7 December to vote, and receive an exclusive Geneco Green Starter Kit (worth $40), that consists of a foldable umbrella, collapsible lunch box, reusable straw, and tote bag.With your pledges, Geneco will be donating $10,000 to Yellow Ribbon Fund, to support their reintegration efforts for inmates, ex-offenders and their families.If you would like to further support Yellow Ribbons efforts, you can also adopt an artwork at the art gallery. "Stop judging, stop labelling. Listen with the heart." At 60-years-old, Jileen Tan embraced a long-held desire to become a prison volunteer, inspired by the profound compassion of Sister Gerard Fernandez years ago, and she continues to be a consistent presence for women inmates in Institution A4. Her weekly visits, which include communion services and counselling, are centred on one simple, powerful act: showing up. As one inmate told her, " During our sentence, the only thing that we still have is time." Jileen's goal is to ensure that time is passed meaningfully, letting them know they are supported.Through her work, Jileen has seen how stigma can affect a person's life in very real ways. "They are like any of us any one of us could be in there too. It is just that we had a different environment, circumstance, and made different choices."Volunteering has taught her to look beyond the surface, connect with empathy, and give hope to those who need it most. YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

On 15 November, HUG Community spent a vibrant afternoon at Blk 200 Toa Payoh for our Community Void Deck Painting, where we partnered with Yellow Ribbon Singapore to refresh and brighten the Mai Gong Bo Jio space. Students, elderly residents, desistors, new volunteers and our friends from HaiDiLao all came down to add colour, laughter and warmth to the walls. What began as a simple paint session quickly grew into a lively gathering of stories, conversations and shared care.This mural means a lot to us. It marks how far HUG has come, how much our community has grown and how many people from different backgrounds now call this space their own. The refreshed MGBJ area is also part of our preparations for HUGs upcoming second anniversary, a milestone that celebrates two years of connection, service and showing up for one another.A big thank you to everyone who contributed their time and heart. The space now carries your colours, your joy and your belief in what community can be. Were excited for many more moments like this as we head into our third year!HUGCommunity MaiGongBoJio VoidDeckPainting YellowRibbonSG CommunityDay VolunteersSG ArtiVolunteers HaiDiLaoVolunteers StrongerTogether SingaporeCommunity HUGTurnsTwo

Creativity, pottery, and second chances, all in one place. We had such a great time at the 5th Singapore Clay Festival at the Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre! Over the course of four days, handcrafted pottery from inmates in the Visual Arts Hub found new homes, in a collaborative effort by Yellow Ribbon Industries and Yellow Ribbon Fund. Each piece tells a story of growth, resilience, and healing, proof that second chances come in many shapes and forms. A heartfelt thank you to everyone who stopped by our booth, shared kind words, and brought home a piece of hope. All sales proceeds are channelled to the Yellow Ribbon Fund to support the rehabilitation and reintegration programmes for inmates, ex-offenders and their families.See you next time! YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances SingaporeClayFestival Clay

Two lives, once broken by addiction now joined by purpose and love. Both Hairi and Azlinda began using drugs during their childhood, and addiction followed them well into adulthood. It cost them years of freedom, family bonds, and self-worth. But after hitting rock bottom, they decided to rebuild, one step, one choice at a time.Through education, counselling, and peer support, they found purpose in helping others on their reintegration journey. Together, they founded .SG, creating a safe space for people undergoing reintegration to share, grow, and rediscover hope. They also share their story through talks with partners like the National Library Board, inspiring others to believe that it's never too late to start afresh.Their journey is proof that no one is too far gone for a second chance. Follow along as their incredible journey comes alive in our upcoming comic series, and you won't want to miss it.YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

From incarcerated gang leader to Head of Technical Services in a Fortune 500 company his journey is proof that second chances can rewrite destinies. At 16, he was caught in fights and gang riots that landed him in maximum security. By 19, he had no qualifications and no stable home. Instead of giving up, he worked odd jobs, studied part-time, and slowly built a career in technical MEP, AV, IT, and construction project management.Today, he serves as a subject matter expert leading his department, while also giving back to the community through volunteering at Meet-the-People Sessions and mentoring others who are rebuilding their lives. His message is simple: "Let's not blame the environment. Adapt, make changes immediately, and never be afraid to ask for the right help when needed." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

Second chances can bloom in unexpected places! Check out this beautiful showcase of hand-painted lanterns, some of which were produced by 60 inmates from various institutions within Changi Prison Complex. Their stunning works shine alongside nearly 1,000 other beautiful lanterns that were produced by the community at 's Colonnade of Lights from 22 September to 12 October 2025, as part of a collaboration between Gardens by the Bay and Yellow Ribbon Project to demonstrate the transformative power of art and the incredible talent of inmates. Each lantern tells a story of creativity, hope, and second chances.Art has no boundaries it connects us all and reminds us that everyone deserves an opportunity to contribute something beautiful to the world. Come witness this inspiring display and celebrate the artistic spirit that unites us all. Gardensbythebay MidAutumnGBB YellowRibbonProject ArtForAll SecondChances CommunityArt Singapore Lanterns VisualArtsHub Inspiration Unity

Celebrating 25 years of transforming lives at the Yellow Ribbon CARE Network Gala Dinner 2025!The Gala was graced by Guest-of-Honour Minister for Law and Second Minister for Home Affairs Mr , alongside more than 800 community partners, donors, sponsors, beneficiaries, and representatives from the CARE Network agencies, to celebrate 25 years of transforming the lives of inmates, ex-offenders and their families.Guests enjoyed musical performances by inmates from the Performing Arts Centre, prison officers, and students from , .sg and took part in auction segments to raise funds. ComChest, the official charity partner for the event, helped facilitate the fundraising efforts. Through the event, over $1.7 million was raised for the Yellow Ribbon Fund, , and .Two new initiatives were also launched during the event:YR Cares, a new charity formed through the merger of the Industrial and Services Co-operative Society Limited (ISCOS), NeuGen Fund, and YRF. Lim Tze Peng-Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary, to recognise the contributions of the late Mr Lim Tze Peng, a Cultural Medallion recipient, who generously donated his artworks to raise funds for the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF).YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonProject SingaporePrisonService SPS BeyondPrisonWalls YRCares SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances SANA NeuGen

From 1 April 2026, Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF), Industrial and Services Co-operative Society Limited (ISCOS) and will come together as Yellow Ribbon Cares (YR Cares). YR Cares is an IPC charity that brings together the strengths of all three organisations. It is dedicated to supporting ex-offenders and their families through reintegration, empowerment, family support and community partnerships.This merger will enable us to create more opportunities, strengthen families and build a stronger ecosystem of care, ensuring that no one walks the reintegration journey alone.Find out more at

Sunny Swee's transformative journey began in 2015, when he was released after serving eight and a half years in prison. Since then, he has created lasting change in his life and is inspiring others to do the same. Yellow Ribbon Fund supported his Bachelor's degree in Mathematics at , and he secured a job as a junior data scientist upon graduation.Today, Sunny is a husband, a father of two beautiful daughters, and the founder of a tuition centre with two partners. He gives back by tutoring inmate students at the Prison School, sharing his story to steer them away from a life of reoffending. YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFundSG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

This is what Second Chances sound like!The Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition 2025 came to a rousing close on 10 Sep 2025, with Acting Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs and Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs, Assoc Prof , gracing the event. With judges , , , , community partners such as and , celebrity mentors and , who co-hosted the Viewers Choice Show with , alongside the inmates loved ones, the competition brought each participant together through music. Inmate finalists performed their hearts out on stage, telling their raw stories of resilience and the courage to begin again.Congratulations to Iqbal, Riduan, Rashid, Nisha and Jasmine for their heartfelt performances that moved the judges and audience alike. Double honours for Iqbal! His song Change received the most public votes to win the Viewers Choice Award, and was also awarded 1st place by our judges in yesterdays finals! To our mentors, judges, partners and everyone who supported the finalists, thank you for believing in second chances and amplifying their voices of hope.Want to hear more from the finalists? Look out for their songs on Spotify, coming your way early 2026!BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances CaptainsOfLives YRSWC2025

This is what Second Chances sound like!The Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition 2025 came to a rousing close on 10 Sep 2025, with Acting Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs and Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs, Assoc Prof , gracing the event. With judges , , , , community partners such as and , celebrity mentors and , who co-hosted the Viewers Choice Show with , alongside the inmates loved ones, the competition brought each participant together through music. Inmate finalists performed their hearts out on stage, telling their raw stories of resilience and the courage to begin again.Congratulations to Iqbal, Riduan, Rashid, Nisha and Jasmine for their heartfelt performances that moved the judges and audience alike. Double honours for Iqbal! His song Change received the most public votes to win the Viewers Choice Award, and was also awarded 1st place by our judges in yesterdays finals! Its a wrap for the Yellow Ribbon Community Arts Festival 2025! Over the past month, the festival brought together powerful artworks, heartfelt music and meaningful conversations about second chances. The opening weekend and exhibition at One Holland Village, welcomed over 7,000 visitors, and the festival reached more than 25,000 visitors in total. The Roving Arts Truck also travelled to the heartlands and schools, connecting with thousands more supporters of the cause and festival. To all our visitors, partners, volunteers and supporters, thank you for journeying with us and showing that rehabilitation and reintegration can only succeed when the community stands together. Your support has transformed this years theme, We Are Each Others Second Chances, from words into a living movement of hope and change. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YellowRibbonCommunityArtsFestiva SG60

Second chances are not about forgetting the past. They are about making space for new memories to take its place. For children of incarcerated parents, the hardest memories are often silent the missed birthdays, unanswered questions, and the silence that follows a relapse.But when change takes root, new moments can begin to grow. Shared by Haziq, this is the story of his journey with his mother, Susanty Binte Yaakop, founder of .bersatu. A reminder that healing takes time, and second chances can bring light to even the darkest parts of the past. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject MySecondChanceStory

Building leaders who champion second chances. At our recent Project Beyond Hiring (PBH) workshop held in July, 11 supervisors from five companies came together to sharpen their skills in supporting ex-offenders at work. Through interactive lessons, role-plays, and coaching, they practised micro skills to communicate better, connect deeper, and lead with empathy."The workshop allowed me to gain a better understanding on how to communicate with ex-offenders effectively. I look forward to putting what I learnt to practice, enhancing my capabilities in leading my team." - Jose from Stuff'd Venture Our final PBH run for the year will take place on 16 and 17 Sep. Employers keen to create inclusive workplaces can express interest via our YRSG Feedback email (link in bio).BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject ProjectBeyondHiring InclusionAtWork Inclusivity

The Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) STAR Bursary held its second get-together session for the year in July 2025, once again bringing together students, families, case workers, and YRF Bursary Committee members in a spirit of celebration and community. The event featured engaging ice breaker activities and an insightful career workshop conducted by Dr Tan Buck Chye, Principal Trainer and Managing Director from Tony Buzan Learning Centre.
